Synset.Definition: the conscious subjective aspect of feeling or emotion
any strong feeling
a persistent illogical feeling of desire or aversion
Synset.Example: he has a thing about seafood
she has a thing about him

Synset.Definition: a feeling of considerable warmth
Synset.Example: the glow of new love
a glow of regret

Synset.Definition: a feeling of faintness and of being ready to swoon
deep feeling or emotion
a strong feeling or emotion
a foolish and usually extravagant passion or love or admiration
a feeling of extreme emotional intensity
Synset.Example: the wildness of his anger

Synset.members: ewn-ardor-n ewn-ardour-n ewn-fervor-n ewn-fervour-n ewn-fervency-n ewn-fire-n ewn-fervidness-n
Synset.Definition: feelings of great warmth and intensity
Synset.Example: he spoke with great ardor

Synset.Definition: violent passion in speech or action
Synset.Example: frightened by the storminess of their argument

Synset.Definition: excessive fervor to do something or accomplish some end
Synset.Example: he had an absolute zeal for litigation

Synset.Definition: tender, romantic, or nostalgic feeling or emotion
extravagant or affected feeling or emotion
insincere pathos
the sentimental feeling you have about someone you once loved but no longer do
(psychoanalysis) a combination of emotions and impulses that have been rejected from awareness but still influence a person's behavior
a complex of males; desire to possess the mother sexually and to exclude the father; said to be a source of personality disorders if unresolved
a complex of females; sexual attraction to the father
a sense of personal inferiority arising from conflict between the desire to be noticed and the fear of being humiliated
mixed feelings or emotions
opposition between two simultaneous but incompatible feelings
Synset.Example: he was immobilized by conflict and indecision

Synset.Definition: an absence of emotion or enthusiasm

Synset.members: ewn-emotionlessness-n ewn-impassivity-n ewn-impassiveness-n ewn-phlegm-n ewn-indifference-n ewn-stolidity-n ewn-unemotionality-n
Synset.Definition: apathy demonstrated by an absence of emotional reactions
a feeling of lack of interest or energy
the feeling that accompanies an unsatisfied state
a cherished desire
Synset.Example: his ambition is to own his own business

Synset.Definition: the widespread aspiration of Americans to live better than their parents did
ambition to equal or excel
the aspiration for national independence felt by people under foreign domination
a desire for bloodshed
the desire to have or do something that you know you should avoid
Synset.Example: he felt the temptation and his will power weakened

Synset.Definition: an intense desire for some particular thing
a feeling of craving something
Synset.Example: an appetite for life
the object of life is to satisfy as many appetencies as possible

Synset.Definition: an appetite for food
Synset.Example: exercise gave him a good stomach for dinner

Synset.Definition: a strong appetite for sweet food
an abnormally strong craving
a specific feeling of desire
Synset.Example: he got his wish
he was above all wishing and desire

Synset.Definition: a mere wish, unaccompanied by effort to obtain
prolonged unfulfilled desire or need
a yearning for something or to do something
a feeling of deep longing
an unrealistic yearning
a sadly pensive longing
longing for something past
a pining for a loved one
a longing to return home
all of the feelings resulting from the urge to gratify sexual impulses
Synset.Example: he wanted a better sex life
the film contained no sex or violence

Synset.Definition: a desire for sexual intimacy
a deep feeling of sexual desire and attraction
Synset.Example: their love left them indifferent to their surroundings
she was his first love

Synset.Definition: a desire for heterosexual intimacy
decline or absence of sexual desire
a feeling of strong sexual desire
desire for sensual pleasures
the arousal of feelings of sexual desire
a form of sexual desire in which gratification depends to an abnormal degree on some object or item of clothing or part of the body
Synset.Example: common male fetishes are breasts, legs, hair, shoes, and underwear

Synset.Definition: (psychoanalysis) a Freudian term for sexual urge or desire
a strong sexual desire
abnormally intense sexual desire in women
abnormally intense sexual desire in men
intense sexual desire
feeling morbid sexual desire or a propensity to lewdness
a strong restless desire
Synset.Example: why this urge to travel?

Synset.Definition: a sudden desire
Synset.Example: he bought it on an impulse

Synset.Definition: a fundamental feeling that is hard to define but that people desire to experience
Synset.Example: he was tingling with pleasure

Synset.Definition: a feeling of extreme pleasure or satisfaction
Synset.Example: his delight to see her was obvious to all

Synset.Definition: a feeling of delight at being filled with wonder and enchantment
a feeling of delight at being entertained
delight in another person's misfortune
the pleasure felt when having a good time
a keen enjoyment of living
vigorous and enthusiastic enjoyment
the feeling caused by agreeable stimuli; one pole of a continuum of states of feeling
the pleasure of remembering some pleasant event
Synset.Example: he basked in the afterglow of his victory

Synset.Definition: a feeling of freedom from worry or disappointment
the comfort you feel when consoled in times of disappointment
Synset.Example: second place was no consolation to him

Synset.Definition: very limited consolation or empathy
Synset.Example: he told me that time heals all wounds but that was cold comfort to me

Synset.Definition: a consoling aspect of a difficult situation
Synset.Example: every cloud has a silver lining
look on the bright side of it

Synset.Definition: the feeling that comes when something burdensome is removed or reduced
Synset.Example: as he heard the news he was suddenly flooded with relief

Synset.Definition: pleasure derived from sexual activities
sexual pleasure derived from inflicting or experiencing pain
sexual pleasure obtained by inflicting harm (physical or psychological) on others
sadism and masochism combined in one person
sexual pleasure obtained from receiving punishment (physical or psychological)
emotional distress; a fundamental feeling that people try to avoid
Synset.Example: the pain of loneliness

Synset.Definition: emotional distress arising during adolescence
the feeling caused by disagreeable stimuli; one pole of a continuum of states of feeling
a sudden sharp feeling
Synset.Example: pangs of regret
she felt a stab of excitement
twinges of conscience

Synset.Definition: pangs of feeling guilty
sustained dull painful emotion
feelings of mental or physical pain
intense feelings of suffering; acute mental or physical pain
Synset.Example: an agony of doubt
the torments of the damned

Synset.Definition: violent pangs of suffering
Synset.Example: death throes

Synset.Definition: an uncomfortable feeling of mental painfulness or distress
soreness or irritation of the skin caused by friction
chafing between two skin surfaces that are in contact (as in the armpit or under the breasts or between the thighs)
psychological suffering
Synset.Example: the death of his wife caused him great distress

Synset.Definition: extreme mental distress
self-imposed distress
(Yiddish) trouble and suffering
a figurative injury (to your feelings or pride)
Synset.Example: he feared that mentioning it might reopen the wound
deep in her breast lives the silent wound
The right reader of a good poem can tell the moment it strikes him that he has taken an immortal wound--that he will never get over it

Synset.Definition: a feeling of pleasure and enjoyment
Synset.Example: I've always had a liking for reading
she developed a liking for gin

Synset.Definition: a predisposition to like something
Synset.Example: he had a fondness for whiskey
she had dismissed him quite brutally, relegating him to the status of a passing fancy, or less

Synset.Definition: a feeling of great liking for something wonderful and unusual
a strong liking
Synset.Example: my own preference is for good literature
the Irish have a penchant for blarney

Synset.Definition: a preference that is only acquired after considerable experience
Synset.Example: martinis are an acquired taste

Synset.Definition: a penchant for something even though it might not be good for you
Synset.Example: he has a weakness for chocolate

Synset.Definition: abnormal attraction to filth
that toward which you are inclined to feel a liking
Synset.Example: her inclination is for classical music

Synset.Definition: an inclination to do something
Synset.Example: he felt leanings toward frivolity

Synset.Definition: an inclination or liking for things involving conflict or difficulty or unpleasantness
Synset.Example: he had no stomach for a fight

Synset.Definition: an inclination contrary to the strongest or prevailing feeling
Synset.Example: his account had a poignant undertow of regret

Synset.Definition: a feeling of liking for another person; enjoyment in their company
a disinclination to quarrel
the friendly hope that something will succeed
the feeling that men should treat one another like brothers
a feeling of liking something or someone good
Synset.Example: although she fussed at them, she secretly viewed all her children with approval

Synset.Definition: a feeling of favorable regard
official approval
a feeling of delighted approval and liking
admiration for Britain and British customs
admiration for great men (or their memory)
admiration for Greece and the Greeks and Greek customs
admiration for women
a feeling of profound love and admiration
a feeling of aversion or antipathy
Synset.Example: my dislike of him was instinctive

Synset.Definition: that toward which you are inclined to feel dislike
Synset.Example: his disinclination for modesty is well known

Synset.Definition: dislike (or fear) of Britain and British customs
dislike experienced as an absence of friendliness
the feeling of being alienated from other people
a feeling of being disliked and alone
a feeling of intense dislike
a feeling of disliking something or what someone is doing
lack of respect accompanied by a feeling of intense dislike
Synset.Example: he was held in contempt
the despite in which outsiders were held is legendary

Synset.Definition: strong feelings of dislike

Synset.members: ewn-abhorrence-n ewn-abomination-n ewn-detestation-n ewn-execration-n ewn-loathing-n ewn-odium-n
Synset.Definition: hate coupled with disgust
feelings of dislike and anxiety
Synset.Example: the cave gave me the creepy-crawlies

Synset.Definition: a strong dislike
Synset.Example: they took a scunner against the United States

Synset.Definition: intense aversion
disgust so strong it makes you feel sick
dislike for new technology
a feeling of thankfulness and appreciation
Synset.Example: he was overwhelmed with gratitude for their help

Synset.Definition: warm friendly feelings of gratitude
a lack of gratitude
a feeling of sympathy for someone or something
Synset.Example: She felt strong concern for those less fortunate

Synset.Definition: a cause for feeling concern
Synset.Example: his major care was the illness of his wife

Synset.Definition: a feeling of excessive concern
a feeling of concern for the welfare of someone (especially someone defenseless)
a feeling of lack of concern
unbiased impartial unconcern
indifference by personal withdrawal
Synset.Example: emotional distance

Synset.Definition: avoiding emotional involvement
an absence of concern for the welfare of others
feelings of extreme heartlessness
a painful emotion resulting from an awareness of inadequacy or guilt
a feeling of shame when you do something immoral
Synset.Example: he has no conscience about his cruelty

Synset.Definition: shame resulting from strong dislike of yourself or your actions
the shame you feel when your inadequacy or guilt is made public
embarrassment deriving from the feeling that others are critically aware of you
feeling embarrassed about yourself
strong feelings of embarrassment
a feeling of embarrassment that leaves you confused
feeling embarrassed due to modesty
anxious embarrassment
a feeling of self-respect and personal worth
a feeling of pride in yourself
an inflated feeling of pride in your superiority to others
feelings of excessive pride
a humble feeling
Synset.Example: he was filled with humility at the sight of the Pope

Synset.Definition: the feeling of patient, submissive humbleness
a feeling of being of little worth
the feeling that accompanies something extremely surprising
Synset.Example: he looked at me in astonishment

Synset.Definition: the feeling of being confounded or overwhelmed
Synset.Example: her departure left him in utter devastation

Synset.Definition: the feeling aroused by something strange and surprising
an overwhelming feeling of wonder or admiration
Synset.Example: he stared over the edge with a feeling of awe

Synset.Definition: the astonishment you feel when something totally unexpected happens to you
a feeling of stupefied astonishment
the feeling of distress and disbelief that you have when something bad happens accidentally
Synset.Example: his mother's death left him in a daze
he was numb with shock

Synset.Definition: the feeling that something is about to happen
an expectation
excited anticipation of an approaching climax
Synset.Example: the play kept the audience in suspense

Synset.Definition: a state of nervous excitement
Synset.Example: in a fever of resentment

Synset.Definition: nervous excitement of an inexperienced hunter
greed and the contagious excitement of a gold rush
a specific instance of feeling hopeful
Synset.Example: it revived their hope of winning the pennant

Synset.Definition: feeling an inappropriate lack of seriousness
a festive merry feeling
a solemn and dignified feeling
an earnest and sincere feeling
sensitivity to emotional feelings (of self and others)
sensitivity leading to easy irritation or upset
refined sensitivity to pleasurable or painful impressions
Synset.Example: cruelty offended his sensibility

Synset.Definition: emotional or moral sensitivity (especially in relation to personal principles or dignity)
Synset.Example: the remark hurt his feelings

Synset.Definition: a feeling of understanding
a sensuous feeling
the feeling of being agitated; not calm
a feeling of restless agitation
a feeling of agitation expressed in continual motion
Synset.Example: he's got the fidgets
waiting gave him a feeling of restlessness

Synset.Definition: a restless desire for change and excitement
an extreme state of worry and agitation
Synset.Example: his stewing over the fight kept him awake most of the night

Synset.Definition: emotional agitation and excitement
violent agitation
keen and shared excitement
Synset.Example: the stage crackled with electricity whenever she was on it

Synset.Definition: a general feeling of excitement and heightened interest
Synset.Example: anticipation produced in me a sensation somewhere between hope and fear

Synset.Definition: a feeling of calm; an absence of agitation or excitement
a feeling of calmness; a quiet and undisturbed feeling
calm and unruffled self-assurance
Synset.Example: he performed with all the coolness of a veteran

Synset.Definition: a state of peace and quiet

Synset.members: ewn-peace-n ewn-peacefulness-n ewn-peace_of_mind-n ewn-repose-n ewn-serenity-n ewn-heartsease-n ewn-ataraxis-n
Synset.Definition: the absence of mental stress or anxiety
a feeling of refreshing tranquility and an absence of tension or worry
Synset.Example: the easiness we feel when sleeping

Synset.Definition: a relaxed comfortable feeling
a strong emotion; a feeling that is oriented toward some real or supposed grievance
a feeling of intense indignation (now used only in the phrase `in high dudgeon')
intense anger (usually on an epic scale)
a feeling of intense anger
Synset.Example: hell hath no fury like a woman scorned
his face turned red with rage

Synset.Definition: a state of fury so great the face becomes discolored
a feeling of intense anger and impatience
a feeling of anger caused by being offended
Synset.Example: he took offence at my question

Synset.Definition: a feeling of righteous anger
a passing state of anger and resentment
a feeling of anger and animosity
Synset.Example: having one's hackles or dander up

Synset.Definition: a persisting angry mood
anger produced by some annoying irritation
a sudden outburst of anger
Synset.Example: his temper sparked like damp firewood

Synset.Definition: a feeling of annoyance at being hindered or criticized
Synset.Example: her constant complaints were the main source of his frustration

Synset.Definition: an exasperated feeling of annoyance
a feeling of intense annoyance caused by being tormented
Synset.Example: so great was his harassment that he wanted to destroy his tormentors

Synset.Definition: an emotion experienced in anticipation of some specific pain or danger (usually accompanied by a desire to flee or fight)
fear resulting from the awareness of danger
a feeling of fear and revulsion
Synset.Example: he gives me the creeps

Synset.members: ewn-frisson-n ewn-shiver-n ewn-chill-n ewn-quiver-n ewn-shudder-n ewn-thrill-n ewn-tingle-n
Synset.Definition: an almost pleasurable sensation of fright
Synset.Example: a frisson of surprise shot through him

Synset.Definition: intense and profound fear
excessive or uncontrollable fear
an overwhelming feeling of fear and anxiety
a panic or extreme discomposure
Synset.Example: it threw her into a swivet

Synset.Definition: a feeling of profound respect for someone or something
Synset.Example: the fear of God
the Chinese reverence for the dead
the French treat food with gentle reverence
his respect for the law bordered on veneration

Synset.Definition: a sudden attack of fear
fear that affects a person about to face an audience
fearful expectation or anticipation
Synset.Example: the student looked around the examination room with apprehension

Synset.Definition: a feeling of alarm or dread
a feeling of evil to come
Synset.Example: a steadily escalating sense of foreboding
the lawyer had a presentiment that the judge would dismiss the case

Synset.Definition: a premonition of something adverse
Synset.Example: a shadow over his happiness

Synset.Definition: a foreboding about what is about to happen
apprehension about what is going to happen
fear of the unknown or unfamiliar or fear of making decisions
timidity that prevents the continuation of a course of action
Synset.Example: I was going to tell him but I got cold feet

Synset.Definition: a feeling of fear of embarrassment
lack of self-confidence
a feeling of diffidence and indecision about doing something
diffidence about self promotion
the feeling of being intimidated; being made to feel afraid or timid
a vague unpleasant emotion that is experienced in anticipation of some (usually ill-defined) misfortune
a strong feeling of anxiety
Synset.Example: his worry over the prospect of being fired
it is not work but worry that kills
he wanted to die and end his troubles

Synset.Definition: an anxious feeling
Synset.Example: care had aged him
they hushed it up out of fear of public reaction

Synset.Definition: a feeling of mild anxiety about possible developments
the anxiety you experience when you feel vulnerable and insecure
feelings of anxiety that make you tense and irritable
feelings of uneasiness
Synset.Example: that guy gave me the willies

Synset.Definition: a feeling caused by uneasiness or apprehension
Synset.Example: with a sinking heart
a sinking feeling in the pit of my stomach

Synset.Definition: uneasiness about the fitness of an action (particularly for reasons of ethics, morals or propriety)
the anxious feeling you have when you have the jitters
an acute but unspecific feeling of anxiety; usually reserved for philosophical anxiety about the world or about personal freedom
feeling no fear
freedom from anxiety or fear
Synset.Example: the watch dog gave her a feeling of security

Synset.Definition: a feeling of trust (in someone or something)
Synset.Example: I have confidence in our team
confidence is always borrowed, never owned

Synset.Definition: emotions experienced when in a state of well-being
(French) happiness and good humor
experiencing joy and pleasure
the emotion of great happiness
an enthusiastic expression of emotion
Synset.Example: rhapsodies of joy

Synset.Definition: a feeling of joy and pride
a feeling of extreme joy
the exultation of victory
the feeling of lively and cheerful joy
Synset.Example: he could hardly conceal his excitement when she agreed

Synset.members: ewn-bang-n ewn-boot-n ewn-charge-n ewn-rush-n ewn-flush-n ewn-thrill-n ewn-kick-n

he does it for kicks

Synset.Definition: excitement and elation beyond the bounds of sobriety
Synset.Example: the intoxication of wealth and power

Synset.Definition: a tingling feeling of excitement (as from teasing or tickling)
a feeling of great (usually exaggerated) elation
a gay feeling
great merriment
a feeling of great happiness
a feeling of facetious merriment
happiness felt in a secure relationship
Synset.Example: with his classmates he felt a sense of belonging

Synset.Definition: a feeling of being at ease in a relationship
a feeling of being intimate and belonging together
Synset.Example: their closeness grew as the night wore on

Synset.Definition: affectionate closeness
Synset.Example: togetherness is the new wonder ingredient in marriage

Synset.Definition: a feeling of spontaneous good spirits
Synset.Example: his cheerfulness made everyone feel better

Synset.Definition: cheerfulness that bubbles to the surface
the cheerful feeling you have when nothing is troubling you
happiness with one's situation in life
the contentment one feels when one has fulfilled a desire, need, or expectation

Synset.Definition: satisfaction with your (or another's) achievements
Synset.Example: he takes pride in his son's success

Synset.Definition: the feeling you have when you are satisfied with yourself
Synset.Example: his complacency was absolutely disgusting

Synset.Definition: an excessive feeling of self-satisfaction
a feeling of satisfaction at having achieved your desires
malicious satisfaction
emotions experienced when not in a state of well-being
sadness caused by grief or affliction
persisting sadness
Synset.Example: nothing lifted the heaviness of her heart after her loss

Synset.Definition: a feeling of thoughtful sadness
a feeling of melancholy apprehension
a feeling of dispirited melancholy
persistent morbid meditation on a problem
sadness on thinking about the evils of the world
intense mournfulness
a feeling of intense unhappiness
Synset.Example: she was exhausted by her misery and grief

Synset.Definition: sadness resulting from being forsaken or abandoned
sadness expressed by weeping
an emotion of great sadness associated with loss or bereavement
Synset.Example: he tried to express his sorrow at her loss

Synset.Definition: sorrow for sin arising from fear of damnation
devastating sorrow and despair
Synset.Example: he is recovering from a broken heart
a broken heart languishes here

Synset.Definition: intense sorrow caused by loss of a loved one (especially by death)
a state of gloomy sorrow
expressing sorrowfulness
(poetry) painful grief
sadness associated with some wrong done or some disappointment
Synset.Example: he drank to drown his sorrows
he wrote a note expressing his regret
to his rue, the error cost him the game

Synset.Definition: a feeling of deep regret (usually for some misdeed)
remorse caused by feeling responsible for some offense

a deep feeling of guilt often experienced by those who have survived some catastrophe that took the lives of many others; derives in part from a feeling that they did not do enough to save the others who perished and in part from feelings of being unworthy relative to those who died
Synset.Example: survivor guilt was first noted in those who survived the Holocaust

Synset.Definition: remorse for your past conduct
a feeling of dreary or pessimistic sadness
a sudden numbing dread
a feeling of dismal cheerlessness
sad feelings of gloom and inadequacy
a feeling of low spirits
Synset.Example: he felt responsible for her lowness of spirits

Synset.Definition: depression resulting from an undermining of your morale
a feeling of being unable to manage
a feeling of sorrow (often self-indulgent) over your own sufferings
feeling downcast and disheartened and hopeless
a feeling of being oppressed
an oppressive feeling of heavy force
Synset.Example: bowed down by the weight of responsibility

Synset.Definition: a longing for something better than the present situation
a feeling of sulky discontent
abnormal depression and discontent
the feeling of being displeased and discontent
Synset.Example: he was never slow to express his dissatisfaction with the service he received

Synset.Definition: the feeling of being bored by something tedious
a general feeling of boredom and dissatisfaction
(always used with a modifier) boredom resulting from overexposure to something
Synset.Example: he was suffering from museum fatigue

political fatigue

Synset.Definition: the feeling of being displeased or annoyed or dissatisfied with someone or something
a feeling of dissatisfaction that results when your expectations are not realized
Synset.Example: his hopes were so high he was doomed to disappointment

Synset.Definition: the feeling that accompanies an experience of being thwarted in attaining your goals
the general feeling that some desire will be fulfilled
Synset.Example: in spite of his troubles he never gave up hope

Synset.Definition: the feeling you have when you have hope
the feeling of being encouraged
the optimistic feeling that all is going to turn out well
feeling sanguine; optimistically cheerful and confident
the feeling that everything is wrong and nothing will turn out well
Synset.Example: they moaned in despair and dismay

Synset.Definition: the despair you feel when you have abandoned hope of comfort or success
acceptance of despair

the feeling that things will turn out badly
a cynical feeling of distrust
a strong positive emotion of regard and affection
Synset.Example: his love for his work

Synset.Definition: selfless love of one person for another without sexual implications (especially love that is spiritual in nature)

the love of a child for a parent
intense feeling of love
a feeling of love or fondness

Synset.Definition: a feeling of affection for a person or an institution
a feeling of protective affection
a feeling of friendship and esteem
Synset.Example: she mistook his manly regard for love

Synset.Definition: a sentimental affection
Synset.Example: she had a soft spot for her youngest son

Synset.Definition: disposition to do good
doing good; feeling beneficent

Synset.Definition: a loving feeling
a warmhearted feeling
feelings of allegiance
the emotion of intense dislike; a feeling of dislike so strong that it demands action
hatred of mankind

feelings of envy and resentment of one social or economic class for toward another

a feeling of hostility that arouses thoughts of attack

Synset.Definition: a feeling of deep and bitter anger and ill-will

Synset.Example: his promotion caused much heartburning among his rivals

Synset.Definition: a feeling of sulky resentment
a resentment strong enough to justify retaliation
Synset.Example: holding a grudge
settling a score

Synset.Definition: a feeling of grudging admiration and desire to have something that is possessed by another
an envious eagerness to possess something
a feeling of jealous envy (especially of a rival)
(psychoanalysis) a female's presumed envy of the male's penis; said to explain femininity
wishing evil to others
doing or causing evil
feeling a need to see others suffer
a malevolent desire for revenge
a characteristic (habitual or relatively temporary) state of feeling
Synset.Example: whether he praised or cursed me depended on his temper at the time
he was in a bad humor

Synset.Definition: an annoyed or irritated mood
a mood or display of sullen aloofness or withdrawal
Synset.Example: stayed home in a sulk

Synset.Definition: a cheerful and agreeable mood
feeling jolly and jovial and full of good humor
an angry and disagreeable mood
a sullen gloomy feeling
a gloomy ill-tempered feeling
a feeling of resentful anger

Synset.Definition: an irritable petulant feeling
feeling easily irritated
a fit of petulance or sulkiness (especially at what is felt to be a slight)
sharing the feelings of others (especially feelings of sorrow or anguish)
sympathy arising from a kind heart
a deep awareness of and sympathy for another's suffering
a feeling of sympathy and sorrow for the misfortunes of others
Synset.Example: the blind are too often objects of pity

Synset.Definition: a feeling of good humor and sympathy through maturity or intoxication or a relaxed state
warm compassionate feelings
the feeling that motivates compassion
compassionate feelings that support a willingness to forgive
a feeling of sympathetic understanding
understanding and entering into another's feelings
a feeling of excitement
a positive feeling of wanting to push ahead with something
a feeling of strong eagerness (usually in favor of a person or cause)
Synset.Example: they were imbued with a revolutionary ardor
he felt a kind of religious zeal

Synset.Definition: joyful enthusiasm
enthusiasm for new technology
The quality of being excessively zealous.
Synset.ILIDefinition: The quality of being excessively zealous.
Synset.Example: We are aware of the public concern for any sort of overzealousness by the law-enforcement people that can cause some embarrassment.

Synset.Definition: the custom of venerating deceased ancestors who are considered still a part of the family and whose spirits are believed to have the power to intervene in the affairs of the living.
Synset.ILIDefinition: the custom of venerating deceased ancestors who are considered still a part of the family and whose spirits are believed to have the power to intervene in the affairs of the living.
Synset.Example: Most of the historically known practices of ancestor worship in Japan are adaptations of Chinese customs.
